an3.52:4.1: Then two old brahmins—elderly and senior, who had lived long and reached the final stage of life, being a hundred and twenty years old—went up to the Buddha,
an3.52:4.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
an3.52:4.4: “We brahmins, Master Gotama, are old, elderly and senior, we’ve lived long and reached the final stage of life, we’re a hundred and twenty years old.
an3.52:4.5: And we haven’t done what is good and wholesome, nor have we made a shelter from fear.
an3.52:4.6: Advise us, Master Gotama, instruct us! It will be for our lasting welfare and happiness.”
an3.52:5.1: “Indeed, brahmins, you’re old, elderly and senior.
an3.52:5.2: And you haven’t done what is good and wholesome, nor have you made a shelter from fear.
an3.52:5.3: This world is burning with old age, sickness, and death,
an3.52:5.4: But restraint here by way of body, speech, and mind is the shelter, protection, island, refuge, and haven for the departed.”
an3.52:7.1: And as the world is on fire
an3.52:8.4: as the good deeds done while living.”
